question.qText: Which of the following is a valid interpretation of this cartoon?

aBtn.aText: The third estate is burdened by the heavy weight of taxes and obligations of those who ride him.
Without the King, nobles and clergy, France would be on its knees.

question.qText: Which of the following is a valid interpretation of this cartoon?

aBtn.aText: The third estate is blind and ignorant, so its only role is to support the educated and wealthy of France.
The third estate’s blindfold may represent the ignorance that results from the denial of educational opportunities.

question.qText: Which of the following is a valid interpretation of this cartoon?

aBtn.aText: It is the right of the other estates to maintain authority and privilege by keeping the third estate under control.
While the third estate struggles and starves, the wealthy grow fat while insisting on enforcement of their privileges.

question.qText: Which of the following is a valid interpretation of this cartoon?

aBtn.aText: The artist used caricature to portray the first and second estates and symbols of torture to create sympathy for the third estate.
The artist ridiculed the third estate by showing him naked and bleeding and portrayed the other estates admiringly.

question.qText: Which of the following statements is true?

aBtn.aText: The artist was probably a skilled member of the third estate.
The artist came from the noble class.

question.qText: Which of the following statements is true?

aBtn.aText: The purpose of the cartoon was to create outrage for the plight of the third estate.
The purpose of the cartoon was to show how depraved and undeserving the members of the third estate were.

question.qText: Which of the following statements is true?

aBtn.aText: The likely audience was the third estate who paid high taxes and did not enjoy any of the privileges of the nobility.
The likely audience as the King who would want to be reminded of the authority he exercised over all of France.

question.qText: Which of the following statements is true?

aBtn.aText: The artist drew the carton from the point of view of the nobility and clergy whose rightly place was on top of the third estate.
The artist identified and sympathized with the third estate and hated the other estates and the king’s representative.
